posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: @bhall-ctre On our end effector, we have a rev through bore encoder wired as an absolute encoder into our CANdi. This CANdi input then is set as the feedback for our pivot motor. The end effector has a hard stop preventing itself from going above a full rotation. The issue we faced was that the encoder returned straight-up absurd values. Sometimes after a power cycle, the values are reported in 1s when it’s supposed to be in 0s. During one of our matches, we also found out that the value returned -3756 as the encoder value. which is clearly not right. Has anyone experienced issues like this is there a fix for this?

posts.name: Dalton
posts.cooked: If you have any logs (especially hoot logs) during one of the matches that had the issue, that would be useful.

posts.name: Rich Wong
posts.cooked: Can you confirm how it’s wired?

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: It is wired into a CANdi. the white signal port goes into the SN1 port of the CANdi. we found out why it was reading values in the 3000.it was because of a severed wire. But sometimes when we power cycle, the encoder values report in the 1s when its supposed to in the 0s. This generally gets fixed if we power cycle one more time but we want to prevent this. Is there any way to disable the encoder and tell the motor controller not take the values when it reports values above 1

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: I dont have any logs for that we found the main issue but the other issue is still stated in the last message

posts.name: Ryan Kostohryz
posts.cooked: @Prince - Did you make any progress with this? We are having the same issue.  We have a Rev through bore encoder wired to a CANdi.  Every time we power cycle the reported position value is vastly different.  Even values outside the -1 to 1 range.  I saw in CTRE Phoenix 5 libs that you could set SensorInitializationStrategy. BootToAbsolutePosition.  I was going to try that but it has been deprecated now for 2025 with the explanation “The Talon FX and CANcoder sensors are always initialized to their absolute position in Phoenix 6.”.  It fails to mention the CANdi however. CTRE ’s documentation seems to indicate it should work, but I’m starting to wonder if you can actually use an absolute encoder through the CANdi.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
We are using REV Through Bore encoders with CANdi’s on our robot successfully. We do see some of the behavior you’re seeing, where the value is sometimes outside of one rotation on boot. However, our mechanisms all rotate over 1 rotation, so we have to handle this anyway.

When you say the reported positions are vastly different, do you mean they’re different outside of the range of one rotation, or actually different? For example, 0.8, -0.2, 1.8, 6.8, -4.2 are all “the same” when normalized within one rotation.

If you’re seeing values that are vastly different outside of one rotation, please share more information. You probably have a bad sensor, bad configuration, or bad wiring.

I should mention, we fried two REV encoders before catching that they cannot be plugged into V+OUT, they need to be powered from 5VOUT. The REV encoders cannot handle 12-volts.

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: We had this issue with some of our mechanism and we decided to remove the discontinuity point in code. This solved most of our issues and we haven’t had this issue again.

posts.name: Ryan Kostohryz
posts.cooked: Thanks to both of you!  Really appreciate the quick response.  After reading more about the discontinuity setting I think adjusting that might take care of it.  We’ve only had it clconnected to the 5VOUT.  Using it on an arm that never goes a full rotation.
